title: Could you really grow potatoes on Mars?; climate change threatens world coffee supply: Table Talk
text:
Here are today's hot food topics:
Could you really grow potatoes on Mars?: The hit movie "The Martian" was tops at the box office over the weekend, and its story about an astronaut stranded on the red planet hinges on an agricultural plot point: Could you grow potatoes on Mars? To stretch out his food supply, Matt Damon's character grows potatoes in an inventive (and gross) way. According to Modern Farmer, you could grow plants on Mars , though the soil lacks the biological material that's needed for them to grow. That's why Damon uses his own "soil amendment."
Once he's got those potatoes, Damon's character microwaves them and douses them with ketchup. Are there other things he could have done to make his survival meals more interesting? Slate came up with a bunch of recipes using the potatoes and some of the other ingredients he had on hand: grape juice, ketchup, olive oil, salt and pepper. ( Modern Farmer , Slate )
Global warming threatens coffee supply: Climate change could make our morning cups of coffee more expensive and difficult to get. According to Bloomberg, drought conditions and rising temperatures were behind a shortfall in Brazil's coffee crop last year, and that rising global temperatures could make it difficult to cultivate Arabica beans, which are the most common type of coffee in the world. ( The Daily Meal )
Food finds around the web: Here are some food morsels worth chewing on.
Mark Bittman talks about why he's leaving food writing, even though he still has plenty to say.
